instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00163: What is 820-00163? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
This arrived with no backlight and at a loss of what it could be.

Using one of our known good screens i do get 3.3V for image but 0v backlight. Both sides <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> 0V  no shorts in diode mode. Also replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>  but no change. F7700 is good.



<CHIP>U7701</CHIP>

pin 5 5v

pin 18  5v

pin 17  0v

pin 11 12.45v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Do you get external video?

<SIGNAL>LCD_HPD</SIGNAL> stays high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: No  external video and  <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD</SIGNAL> stays high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Do you get internal image for sure?
Disconnect internal LCD and test again external video.

Check for USB activity.
Caps Lock reacts?
You may have GPU issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I do get a chime when it first starts and GPU vcore is a steady .860V 

No do not know if internal image is there for sure. I assumed with getting 5V and 3V from screen

no external video with internal LCD disconnect.

could It be faulty <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> with pin 17 of  <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> 0V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Missing internal/external image at same time, points more to GPU problem; heat it for test.
Backlight issue cannot block external video.

Very low chance to be <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>, but you can change it (just in case).
Confirm USB activity after chime.
You should make an idea if board continues working, or just stuck after chime.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Before heating GPU decided to try new bios just in case. Looks like old bios was bad. Now getting blinking light on usb drive and confirmed external image. still nothing on internal.

<SIGNAL>PP5VR3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> now 0v 

<SIGNAL>BUF_5V_EN</SIGNAL> only 0.34V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Both must appear at least in the first few seconds, when chimes.
<SIGNAL>LCD_HPD</SIGNAL> should go high at same time, to maintain the voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Yes, they do appear within the first few seconds and then drop

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I hope you've checked with screen connected.
In fact, <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD</SIGNAL> can't appear other way.

From previous post, I understood you got steady voltage.
Try other BIOS, known good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Yes, the test was done with screen connected.

using this bios you provided awhile back from here. 

 [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-bios-fix-required.56644/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Try another file, maybe the backup.
And check if <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD</SIGNAL> stays high; just for test...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Url from paul no longer works.

Tried other bios from 00426 board thats fully functional. <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD</SIGNAL> is steady now and  <SIGNAL>PP5VR3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> back to 5V

Also have confirmed usb activity and external image

Still 0V on backlight

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Did you test with compatible known good screen for sure?
Backlight adjust comes from T-CONN (I2C bus), placed inside LCD assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: yes, same screen assembly works fine on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
